1.brief: to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)
to hear intelligently (often with implication of attention, obedience, etc.; causatively, to tell, etc.)
Jabin, the name of two Canaanitish kings
Chatsor, the name (thus simply) of two places in Palestine and of one in Arabia
to send away, for, or out (in a great variety of applications)
near, with or among; often in general, to
Jobab, the name of two Israelites and of three foreigners
near, with or among; often in general, to
Shimron, the name of an Israelite and of a place in Palestine
near, with or among; often in general, to

2.brief: near, with or among; often in general, to
who, which, what, that; also (as an adverb and a conjunction) when, where, how, because, in order that, etc.
properly, hidden, i.e. dark; used only of the north as aquarter (gloomy and unknown)
a mountain or range of hills (sometimes used figuratively)
a desert; especially (with the article prefix) the (generally) sterile valley of the Jordan and its continuation to the Red Sea
the south (from its drought); specifically, the Negeb or southern district of Judah, occasionally, Egypt (as south to Palestine)
Kinneroth or Kinnereth, a place in Palestine
Lowland, i.e. (with the article) the maritime slope of Palestine

a sea (as breaking in noisy surf) or large body of water; specifically (with the article), the Mediterranean Sea; sometimes a large river, or an artifical basin; locally, the west, or (rarely) the south

3.brief: a Kenaanite or inhabitant of Kenaan; by implication, a pedlar (the Canaanites standing for their neighbors the Ishmaelites, who conducted mercantile caravans)

a sea (as breaking in noisy surf) or large body of water; specifically (with the article), the Mediterranean Sea; sometimes a large river, or an artifical basin; locally, the west, or (rarely) the south
an Emorite, one of the Canaanitish tribes
a Chittite, or descendant of Cheth
a Perizzite, one of the Canaanitish tribes
a Jebusite or inhabitant of Jebus
a mountain or range of hills (sometimes used figuratively)
a Chivvite, one of the aboriginal tribes of Palestine
the bottom (as depressed); only adverbially, below (often with prepositional prefix underneath), in lieu of, etc.
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
Mitspah, the name of two places in Palestine

4.brief: to go (causatively, bring) out, in a great variety of applications, literally and figuratively, direct and proxim.
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
an encampment (of travellers or troops); hence, an army, whether literal (of soldiers) or figurative (of dancers, angels, cattle, locusts, stars; or even the sacred courts)
adverb or preposition, with (i.e. in conjunction with), in varied applications; specifically, equally with; often with prepositional prefix (and then usually unrepresented in English)
a people (as a congregated unit); specifically, a tribe (as those of Israel); hence (collectively) troops or attendants; figuratively, a flock
abundant (in quantity, size, age, number, rank, quality)

a vehicle; by implication, a team; by extension, cavalry; by analogy a rider, i.e. the upper millstone

properly, vehemence, i.e. (with or without preposition) vehemently; by implication, wholly, speedily, etc. (often with other words as an intensive or superlative; especially when repeated)

to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)

water; figuratively, juice; by euphemism, urine, semen
to feed on; figuratively, to consume; by implication, to battle (as destruction)

properly, leanness, i.e. (figuratively) limitation; only adverbial, merely, or conjunctional, although
properly, to swell up, i.e. be (causatively, make) redundant

23.brief: to take (in the widest variety of applications)
Jehoshua (i.e. Joshua), the Jewish leader
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
who, which, what, that; also (as an adverb and a conjunction) when, where, how, because, in order that, etc.
perhaps properly, to arrange; but used figuratively (of words), to speak; rarely (in a destructive sense) to subdue
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
near, with or among; often in general, to
Mosheh, the Israelite lawgiver
to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)
Jehoshua (i.e. Joshua), the Jewish leader
properly, something inherited, i.e. (abstractly) occupancy, or (concretely) an heirloom; generally an estate, patrimony or portion
Jisrael, a symbolical name of Jacob; also (typically) of his posterity
a section (of Levites, people or soldiers)
a scion, i.e. (literally) a stick (for punishing, writing, fighting, ruling, walking, etc.) or (figuratively) a clan
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
to repose (usually figurative)
a battle (i.e. the engagement); generally, war (i.e. warfare)
